thread.title_full: Bees are taught to play football

title: Bees are taught to play football
text: Share 20 shares The study, published in the journal Science, placed bumblebees on a platform and trained them to move a yellow ball from the edge to the centre. When they were successful, a trapdoor in the ball would open, releasing a delicious sugar solution as their reward. To learn the technique, the bees were trained under one of three conditions. Some observed a previously trained bee move the furthest ball to the centre to gain reward, others received a ‘ghost’ demonstration, using a magnet to move the ball, and a third group received no demonstration, where they found the ball already at the centre of the platform with a reward. The bees that observed the technique from a live bee or a plastic one, were more efficient, showing bees can be trained. It builds on previous studies showing they can pull levers and strings to access food, but the new study shows for the first time they can perform behaviour not linked to their natural foraging habits which they normally do not need. The bees that observed the technique from a live bee or a plastic one, were more efficient, showing bees can be trained Joint lead author Dr Clint Perry, also from Queen Mary University of London, said: ‘We wanted to explore the cognitive limits of bumblebees by testing whether they could use a non-natural object in a task likely never encountered before by any individual in the evolutionary history of bees.’ The insects further showed they could improve upon their learned behaviour by using differently coloured balls. Joint lead author Dr Olli Loukola, from the university’s School of Biological and Chemical Sciences, said: ‘This shows an impressive amount of cognitive flexibility, especially for an insect.’ He added: ‘It may be that bumblebees, along with many other animals, have the cognitive capabilities to solve such complex tasks, but will only do so if environmental pressures are applied to necessitate such behaviours.’ Share or comment on this article 20
